awd_titl_txt: I Am STEM: Mindset and Belongingness in Underrepresented STEM Populations
awd_abstract_narration:
The "I Am STEM" project recruits and awards scholarships to a cohort of financially needy and academically talented students, approximately 18 freshmen and 16 sophomores each year, at the Dunwoody Campus of Perimeter College of Georgia State University. This project is designed to increase enrollment and persistence in the STEM disciplines and links to existing student support structures for enrolling, retaining, graduating and transferring associate degree students. 

The Project develops the participants' deeper learning competencies through two components: 1) developing a STEM Mindset and 2) fostering STEM Belongingness. To assist students in developing a STEM mindset, the Project utilizes two key components: a First Year Experience course and problem-based learning experiences targeting STEM gateway courses. To foster belongingness, the Project employs faculty mentoring, "World of Work" experiences, and a community service initiative to establish an ongoing learning community. "World of Work" experiences include industry tours and guest speakers; the community service initiative allows participants to develop personal and professional skills while engaging primary school students in activities that will help the children discover the joy and wonder associated with science, technology, engineering, and mathematics. The intellectual merit of the project is demonstrated through a research-based comprehensive assessment and evaluation plan. The results of the project generates knowledge regarding the factors that strengthen the participation of underrepresented students in STEM. The results of the project, as well as the details with regard to process and application of intervention approaches, serve as a roadmap for other access institutions to replicate the project strategies and therefore will have a broader impact.

inst.inst_name: Georgia State University Research Foundation, Inc.
inst.org_lgl_bus_name: GEORGIA STATE UNIVERSITY RESEARCH FOUNDATION INC

por.por_cntn:
I Am STEM was a project to help students develop an academic mindset and increase their feeling of belongingness in STEM; scholars were financially needy STEM students with academic potential at the Dunwoody Campus of Perimeter College, an associate-degree granting unit of Georgia State University. We are an access institution with a liberal arts curriculum; many students are from groups underrepresented in STEM who can be academically successful if given the needed support.

I Am STEM scholars met for two hours every Friday morning of the academic year to participate in activities designed to foster success.
Gateway Enrichment Experiences were intended to develop problem solving and critical thinking skills.  General visualization, critical thinking questions/problems, and course-specific problems requiring critical thought were addressed. In addition, one session per semester was an interactive presentation on a topic such as spatial visualization, the use of discrete math, and approaches to problem solving.

Academic success was routinely discussed in our weekly meetings, including topics such as mindset, self-regulated learning, metacognition, time management, goal-setting, and the relationship between health and academic success.  We also had a success speaker present once per semester.  

In addition, scholars participated in a variety of World of Work opportunities: speakers of all ages and backgrounds from institutions and companies such as Delta Tech Ops, Georgia Institute of Technology, the Centers for Disease Control, United Launch Alliance, and Cox Enterprises talked with scholars. Scholars also took field trips such as to the Georgia Tech CubeSat lab, Delta Tech Ops, and NanoLumens.


The I Am STEM scholars were involved in a Pay it Forward initiative in which they took activities to elementary schools.  The scholars enjoyed this outreach because it gave them a chance to share the fun and exciting parts of science that is sometimes overshadowed in university classes.  This initiative also expanded the broader impact of the Project by engaging children and allowing them to envision themselves as scientists and engineers.

Finally, each scholar also was assigned a faculty advisor/mentor with whom he or she met regularly to discuss progress and a personalized course of study.

During the time that GSU was online at the end of the Spring 2020 semester and the 2020-2021 academic year, I Am STEM continued to meet weekly to and engage in program activities, but in an online setting.  

The goals of I Am STEM were to provide improved education opportunities for students (targeting females and underrepresented minorities) entering STEM pathways by removing financial barriers, to generate knowledge regarding persistence in community colleges by examining the impact of STEM interventions on students, and to increase numbers of well-rounded, well-educated employees in areas of national need by increasing the persistence of students majoring in STEM disciplines.

We served 85 students in 5 annual cohorts, awarding $551,440 in scholarships to financially needy students of academic potential, including a large number (71%) in underrepresented populations.  We accepted over 95% of eligible students who applied.  The positive impact of I Am STEM is reflected in the large percentages of students that continued for multiple semesters in the Project who remained enrolled and in a STEM pathway.

The retention rate of first-time, full-time first-year STEM students on which our project objective was based was 68%. In contrast, 93% of I Am STEM scholars were still enrolled in school one year later, including 93% of 60 in an underrepresented population.

The 71 scholars in the 2016-2019 cohorts stayed with us an average of 3.1 semesters; of the scholars who did not leave after their first semester, 83% (including 83% of underrepresented populations) stayed in STEM and completed the program or transferred before completion.  100% of scholars in the 2020 cohort transferred to a four-year institution or remain enrolled in STEM at Perimeter College for Fall 2021.

One of the missions of Perimeter College is to prepare students for transfer to a senior institution; I Am STEM is helping students do this at a higher rate than the Perimeter College 4-year graduation and transfer rate of 43%.

The Research Director conducted focus groups with the I Am STEM scholars in February 2020 and 2021.  Scholars were provided a list of the eight GSU College to Career competencies and associated skills and asked to describe whether and how they believed their participation in I Am STEM helped develop these skills. Scholars enthusiastically described the value of working through problems in small groups, improving oral communication skills, learning to communicate in a professional manner, and learning more about STEM careers.

The overarching goals of I Am STEM centered on academic mindset and belongingness.  The high persistence rate ? both in STEM and in higher education in general ? and prevailing theme in the focus groups of the community and camaraderie the scholars developed with one another and with their faculty mentors are evidence of the success of this Project.


Last Modified: 10/29/2021
Modified by: Brooke P Skelton
